name: Big Bend Holiday Hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This was our first stay with the Holiday Hotel, we usually stay at Mimi's place but our usual room was not available Memorial Day weekend. The Iveys have done a great job in adding lodging space here and the Candililla House is a great example. The two bedroom casita has plenty of room for two couples or a family. The detached washroom and shower (two seperate locations) were fully equipped and met all of our needs. The outdoor space is ample and provides great views of the Chisos and the rest of the park.
reviews.title: Agreat addition to the Ghosttown

reviews.text: Air conditoning was ample in the 110 degree afternoon. A small frig, microwave and plates, cups glasses were also nice. You would be making a good choice here.
reviews.title: Great location, close to Big Bend & best restaurants in Terlingua

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Stayed in Candellia House, which is a home owned/operated by the Holiday Hotel. The house is great, but it's best to know what you're getting beforehand. The best part is that the house is as advertised and the photos are a very good representation of the property. The house sits among other old dilapidated dry-stacked stone homes that are authentic remenants of the quicksilver mining boom of the early 1900s.
reviews.title: Great Location in Ghost Town Terlingua, Details Need Work

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Candellia house has been dressed up, painted and decked-out in funky tile and SW furniture. The house has nice outdoor areas that allow guests to socialize, watch the sun go down, etc. The bathroom and shower areas are very cool and artsy, but they are detatched from the actual house. For our visit, that wasn't a problem. There is very little, if any, traffic near the house. Plus, the owners provide nice bathrobes to walk back and forth between the house and shower. It's just a few feet away, but it's a nice touch. The shower and bath were clean and we had plenty of hot water.
reviews.title: Be a part of the ghost town; great alternative to staying in the park

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Another big hit is that the house is just a 5 min walk away to the best restaurant in Terlingua, the Starlight Theatre. We stayed in the area for a week and ate there three times. The local atmosphere was great, live music every night that was West Texas appropriate, and the food and prices were very good.
reviews.title: Unexpected luxury in an authentic ghost town

description: The Holiday Hotel is no franchise resort. It's perfect for raucous revelry or a romantic rendezvous, or both...You'll find many things in the Ghost Town in the exact condition they've been in for centuries, and that's great for exploring, but at the end of the day you'll want air conditioning.Named for the reddish mercury ore that fueled the industry that was the Chisos Mine, this room belies the Ghost Town location and offers a rustic yet elegant experience.The fancy indoor bathroom that we're so proud of is -- ahem... -- a short walk down the scenic porch, marked Room # 1B. It's a Terlingua tradition that has caught on big in Europe. erlingua chic, the Candililla House is great for either couples or families. Perched on a hillside, it offers an everchanging view of sunsets, starlight, and thunderstorms. There is a patio outside the walls and another within.The El Patron Suite is suitable for business meetings, but they're frowned on around the Ghost Town. Instead, have a few amigos/amigas join you for a festive evening. Walk over to the famous Terlingua Cemetery to greet the ghosts, or just watch the sunset with everyone on the porch over at the Trading Post. Bring your guitar (but not the accordion.)The Candelilla House gets its name from the local cactus that was gathered by the locals and used in the manufacture of women's makeup products. The owners' family operated both a trading post and a processing facillity that kept this Mexican tradition alive.Just down the road a piece from the end of the earth is the Rio Grande Rock House. This is not some neo-cowboy fantasy replica. It's real by-God Texas history. Built in the early 19th century as a trading post for trappers and settlers from both sides of the border, it's still in the same family.We're proud to be out on the fringe of Texas. Come on down.Free Parking - Wireless Adjacent* - Indoor Plumbing**If you stand out on the porch and hold your laptop up real high, you may get a signal.*The indoor plumbing is not necessarily "in your room."
